“ We grant leave in respect of each of these applications , as we consider the sentence imposed by Judge PERSON in respect of each of the defendants was unduly lenient . ( … )

Much has been said about the delay in this case . It does indeed seem a very long time . But it has to be borne in mind that much of the delay in the hearing of these applications has resulted from the fact that CARDINAL of the defendants chose , as was their right , to appeal against conviction .

We regard conduct of the sort involved here , that is to say working to create a false market in shares in companies involved in a GPE takeover , and in order to influence the fate of that takeover , as a very serious matter . Not only may it lead to a fraud on shareholders , but it causes considerable damage to the reputation of GPE , which is very important to the whole country ; and damage to the confidence of the public in its institutions .

We consider it very unlikely , therefore , that when such conduct comes before the courts for sentence that a Community Service Order could ever be sufficient punishment . We have no hesitation in concluding that it was inappropriate , that is to say too lenient , in respect of the conduct in this case . True no actual false market was created , but it was not for want of trying . ( … )

Dealing first with [ Mr X ] . We view him as the instigator and leader of the operation . In our judgment , the right sentence which should have been passed on him by a trial judge upon conviction , additional to compensation and the costs order , was DATE imprisonment . We now start by taking into account that he did serve the period of community service that he was called upon to serve , and served it well apparently . Next we deduct from the sentence what has come to be known as the ‘ discount for double jeopardy’ . After those deductions , we arrive at a sentence , to run from DATE , of DATE imprisonment . We further disqualify him from holding a directorship of a public company for DATE from DATE .

Turning to [ the applicant ] . He was an active and powerful second in command . The right sentence in his case , we believe , would have been CARDINAL months’ imprisonment . Again we do the discounting that we did in the case of [ Mr X ] ; and we arrive at a sentence of CARDINAL months’ imprisonment , starting from DATE . We disqualify him from holding a directorship in a public company for DATE . ”
CARDINAL . The compensation and costs orders remained . The applicant had already completed the community service to which he had originally been sentenced .

In addition to the general regime of appeals against decisions of ORG , the Attorney General may , in certain circumstances and where it appears to him that a sentence of ORG has been unduly lenient , apply to ORG for leave to refer the case to it to review the sentence . The principal relevant provisions are to be found in LAW of LAW DATE . An application for leave must be made within DATE of the sentence . Where the Court of Appeal grants leave , it will consider a sentence “ unduly lenient ” where “ it falls outside the range of sentences which the judge , applying his mind to all the relevant factors , could reasonably consider appropriate ” ( Attorney General ’s Reference No . DATE , Cr . App . PERSON ) CARDINAL ) .
